Remarks: Since ISO14822:2011(e)  similar to ECMAScript on default (Grammar Description)
Omitted in the language report  and in GHC's Hierarchical Libraries
REs are written as strings in source code: all backslashes must be doubled  harming readability.
Limited but REs are first-class citizens of the language with a specific /.../mod syntax.
REs are part of the language core library using PCRE built-in and an optional wrapper for (C code) ICU is available.
Uses simplified  limited dialect; can be bound to more powerful library  like PCRE or an alternative parser like LPeg.
Standard library includes PCRE-based re and nre modules  as well as various alternatives (ex. strutils  pegs (Parsing Expression Grammar matching)  strscans  parseutils  etc.).
Free Pascal 2.6+ ships with TRegExpr from Sorokin and two other regular expression libraries; See wiki.lazarus.freepascal.org/Regexpr.

As of 2010[update]  the standard module is generally regarded as deprecated;[7] often recommended libraries are pcre (with full support for PCRE) and re (which is not as complete but claims better performance and provides frontends to popular syntaxes: PCRE  Perl  Posix  Emacs  shell globbing).

Software license: Artistic License  or GNU General Public License
Remarks: Full  central part of the language
Has two implementations  with PCRE being the more efficient in speed  functions
According to regex(3)  available from at least 4.4BSD (if not earlier)
Python has two major implementations  the built in re and the regex library.
Ruby 1.8  Ruby 1.9  and Ruby 2.0 and later versions use different engines; Ruby 1.9 integrates Oniguruma  Ruby 2.0 and later integrate Onigmo  a fork from Oniguruma.
The primary regex crate does not allow look-around expressions. There is an Oniguruma binding called onig that does.
Tcl library doubles as a regular expression library.

Software license: Proprietary; usable for free on a limited scale on the Wolfram Development platform.
